intro: Biscutella intermedia var. macroclada, commonly known as the large-flowered biscuitroot, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant is characterized by its basal rosette of fleshy, lobed leaves and clusters of small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in coastal sage scrub and chaparral habitats. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and potential medicinal research.
